Regretfully acknowledging that the public consensus is for a rate increase. Although not all the Board members of the Federal Reserve agree, the balance of power is shifting to a majority in agreement to increase rates.  Mostly to save FACE, help boost profits in the banking industry, deal with the 4.5 trillion in assets on  their books and of course to avoid a stock market reaction if they do not increase rates. All these reasons pale in the face of a global reality, The New Normal. Central Banks around the world are adjusting their currencies in anticipation of the rate change while reducing their bank rates. They want to capture the profits for their exporters as the dollar rises and American goods become more expensive. 
The America Federal Reserve can  claim a victory over the banking collapse in 2008, they are bringing back a stable interest environment. Like most politicians short sighted solutions keep you in power.

Yellen's statements have been strong towards the possibility of increase in Dec up till now, confirming this. One of the Fed's markers for part of their dual mandate, unemployment rate, was perceived to be slowing in its decrease during the Oct meeting, but data from Nov upwardly revised previous job reports and was surprisingly positive, pushing unemployment strongly downward towards the economically magic number of 5%. I believe the Fed sees the core CPI edging towards 2% as a positive sign to go forward with the rate increase, despite the total CPI still being lower than their long-term goal of 2%, largely due to low energy costs. The Fed's mid-range estimate of GDP growth is moderate and I don't believe something that will affect the decision to raise rates right now. I will be looking forward to the November CPI release on the morning of Dec 15th for more information to adjust my forecast before the Dec 16th meeting.

Not changing forecast but adding commentary:  The issue is the credit markets not the stock market.  Liquidity has all but disappeared in the junk bond market spiking interest rates and widening the spread as capital flees to treasuries (safety).  So the Fed has forces pushing itself in both directions - (1) not to raise since there's market turmoil and (2) to raise since the pension funds are even in more of a bind with lowering yields.   Longer term, the pensions crisis is a larger one and the Fed knows this so they have to start raising interest rates.  If they don't do this year all credibility will be lost and the market will (violently) set its own rates as they have done with the junk bond market.  So overall the Fed's primary concern must be to maintain market faith that they are in control ... even though they clearly are not.

With a big sell of in the stock market and drop in oil prices, there are concerns of deflation and recession around the world although the unemployment rate in the U.S. is still holding at 5%, so the Fed may back off on the anticipated 25 basis points rate hike next week. But counterintuitive forces may think that a rate hike would mean that the Fed thinks that the U.S. economy will continue to get stronger which would be good for the stock markets and prevent future inflation.

The Fed has committed to it and the voices from the markets are becoming shrill. They already backed off once over a yer ago after the "temper tantrum". If they back off this minuscule and relentlessly-telegraphed hike, they lose credibility at least for Yellen's term.

The "Economist" concurs today, 12/12/15,  stalling a rise  in interest rates can avoid stalling the emerging growth in our economy.  http://www.economist.com/news/leaders/21679793-federal-reserve-set-raise-interest-rates-first-time-2006-its-next-step?frsc=dg%7Ca Federal Reserve needs  to stall on a rate increase or they could stall what economic growth is emerging. 1.	The source of the pressure to move rates higher is less about employment and inflation and more about bank profits.
http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/49f8b480-525e-11e5-b029-b9d50a74fd14.html#ixzz3tfAUIoWs The banks could use a boost. According to the Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis, US banks’ net interest margin (the gap between what they pay for funding and what they charge to lend) peaked at more than 3.8 per cent in 2010 and is now less than 3 per cent. That is a big chunk of lost profits. In Europe margins are lower still — Germany’s Deutsche Bank, for example, had a net interest margin of just 1.4 per cent last year. 2.	On October 28th, the majority of the Federal Reserve members voted not to raise rates because:
When the Committee decides to begin to remove policy accommodation, it will take a balanced approach consistent with its longer-run goals of maximum employment and inflation of 2 percent. The Committee currently anticipates that, even after employment and inflation are near mandate-consistent levels, economic conditions may, for some time, warrant keeping the target federal funds rate below levels the Committee views as normal in the longer run.” Voting for this action: Janet L. Yellen, William C. Dudley, Lael Brainard, Charles L. Evans, Stanley Fischer, Dennis P. Lockhart, Jerome H. Powell, Daniel K. Tarullo, and John C. Williams. Voting against this action: Jeffrey M. Lacker.

From reviewing the data, I still think there is a strong case to keep rates stable as I've stated before (wages just starting to increase for the middle class with very low inflation and core inflation, as well as impact on the EU and emerging markets) but the voices expressing these concerns have been less prevalent in the last few weeks. At this point if the Fed were not to raise rates it would probably have more of a destabilizing impact on the American markets as most firms have adjusted for the expected hikes.

I’m debating between what the fed “ought to” do and probability of what they “will do”. In the past the two were the same most of the time, but this time around it doesn’t seem that clear. I believe that the Fed should wait till next year as the economy is reaching a point where most metrics are only now turning “green” and there does not seem to be any significant threat of inflation. Also, the impact of a rate hike has the potential to jolt emerging markets significantly, considering China has already seen significant capital outflows. However Yellen’s statements seem to hint more strongly towards a December hike. To a lesser extent I think President Obama would also like to start his last year in office and say something positive about the economy at the state of the union on Jan 16th with the first rate hike behind him.
Hence I’m changing my forecast from 45% to 60%.

One okay jobs number does not a rate hike case make. In fact, there's been quite a slew of recent weaker data as summarised in this comment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/55692. In particular, the large drop in the GDPnow forecast to 1.5% is a significant indicator of the economy's fragility to the higher US dollar and global economic weakness.  On the other hand, Yellen has been out saying an earlier rate hike would be better to reduce the risk of an overly steep hiking path to combat an unexpected burst of inflation. I have no idea where this inflation would come from, given the massive commodities oversupply globally, and the consistent near-zero real wages growth domestically, which reflects the large amount of shadow slack in the labour market consistent with the much lower post-crisis participation rate. There's very little reason to hike, besides making some symbolic 'show of confidence'. Both the markets and consensus forecasts have overestimated the probability of hiking multiple times over the past few years. Yellen seems to be a naturally conservative and risk-averse person, so I think hiking is still quite unlikely. Holding at 10% probability.

Well, despite the rhetoric out of the fed, if they move forward with a rate hike, it's certainly NOT to cool an overheating economy. There are risks for staying at zero for too long, and this may ultimately be the driver. Then again, if this was understood, they should have hiked in 2013 or 2014, during significantly more favorable economic conditions. Perceptions have been massaged upwards, and it's clearly apparent even on "good judgment" that poor judgment is being reflected in what comprises "good" economic data, as the global and domestic economy continues to reflect deterioration and general weakness. I am baffled by the number of comments relating to "strong economy", "good data" etc., when there is no evidence to be found below the headlines.  Today's 211k November jobs number while "okay" judging by annual trends and right about the mean for the past 4 years, is still well below November 2014's (423k) and November 2013's (317k). The fact is, there is typically a surge in hiring during this time frame due to the anticipation of the holiday season; however, we did NOT see that this year. ISM manufacturing dropped last month, below expectations and is in contraction. http://www.cnbc.com/2015/12/01/us-ism-manufacturing-nov-2015.html ISM services dropped significantly last month, below expectations. http://www.marketwatch.com/story/ism-services-index-falls-to-559-in-november-2015-12-03 US consumer confidence fell by the most since 2011, to its lowest level in a year. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-03/consumer-comfort-at-one-year-low-as-u-s-buying-climate-dims US exports fall to lowest level in three years. http://www.marketwatch.com/story/us-exports-fall-to-lowest-level-in-three-years-2015-12-04 Atlanta fed's current forecast for Q4 GDP is only 1.5%.  https://www.frbatlanta.org/cqer/research/gdpnow.aspx?panel=1 And this is just the tip of the iceberg considering the severe economic problems in China and the EU. This is the kind of data the fed would normally be considering further EASING ,not tightening. I think this represents our first opportunity for a significant policy error this cycle... I'm staying well below consensus for what I believe to be a significant overestimation  of  current economic conditions. I don't believe the economy can handle higher interest rates--not even the modest and gradual hiking cycle, that is being telegraphed by the fed. I suspect that I have a good chance of being wrong this month, only to be proven right next year.

The Futures' market is predicting 79%, but I think it's a bit conservative - I'm bumping up to 85%. According to the Federal Reserve (see decision link below), there are three things they are currently thinking about:
1) Inflation rate (seems to be flat around 0.2%)
2) Unemployment rate (trending downwards to 5%)
3) Effect on world markets (which are still fragile) So for now inflation is below where they want it, and employment has been consistently improving. So on the one hand, they could raise and start normalising the rate again (they are abnormally low, apparently), or on the other hand, not raise the rates, and maybe keep the jobs momentum going. I might have to adjust depending on the jobs report this afternoon, but the expectation is that it will remain at 5%, which will point towards a rate increase. What I'm thinking of doing next is looking at a sectorwise composition of the jobs increases, and the relationship to exports. The best argument against a rates increase, in my opinion, would be the damage it does to developing markets, and in turn the impact upon US exports. I'm still not sure of what will be a good proxy for the state of world economy - suggestions welcome! Previous predicition rationale: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/51903

"An overly aggressive increase in rates ... would at undercut the economic expansion, necessitating a lasting return to low interest rates," Yellen said in the letter. ~~~ And maybe the most important link, from my perspective, an explainer on Fed futures from Nov 24: http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/f4330f9a-921e-11e5-bd82-c1fb87bef7af.html#axzz3sbWHtCt9 But interest rate futures imply there is still a 25 per cent chance that the Federal Reserve will stay on hold. Why the apparent discrepancy? ... But the easiest way to see what investors expect policymakers to do is to track the Fed funds futures, contracts that are settled at a price determined by where the Fed’s interest rate is in the month of expiry. Simply put, the price is 100 minus the effective Fed funds rate at the time. The December contract currently trades at 99.78, so that implies that investors predict an interest rate of 0.22 per cent, but crucially — and complicating the calculations — that is the average over the month. Next year, the Fed funds future for December 2016 is trading at 99.19, which implies an average Fed funds rate of 0.81 per cent in that month. However, those numbers are misleadingly clean, given the complex underlying calculations, and both Bloomberg and the CME’s estimates arguably underplay the likelihood markets really assign to the chances of lift-off in December. Part of the problem is that the Fed moved to an interest rate corridor in the wake of the financial crisis. Rather than targeting a single Fed funds rate by tweaking the amount of money in the system — the traditional way of easing or tightening monetary policy — the US central bank in 2008 moved to a range of 0 per cent to 0.25 per cent. As the chart below shows, the effective Fed funds rate has traded within this corridor since then, and averaged around 13.2 basis points — roughly midway between the two points — since 2009. [einsteinjs: the current Fed funds rate sits at 0.12 --> http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/25/usa-fedfunds-idUSL1N13K0SU20151125 ] ... The interest rate rise probability calculation depends on whether the Fed goes back to a specific target, or — as is far more likely — it simply lifts its corridor target by 25bp. If so, where the effective Fed funds rate settles is pivotal for estimating what probability is implied by the relevant contracts. ... For example, if the effective Fed funds rate ends up closer to the lower end of the central bank’s range then the likelihood of a rate rise implied by Fed funds futures contracts is, in fact, much higher. If the effective Fed funds rate goes to 37.5bp, then the probability is about 70 per cent, as Bloomberg’s calculations imply. But if it is dragged higher by the Fed’s IOER tool then the likelihood implied is lower, points out George Pearkes, an analyst at Bespoke Investment Group. ... On the whole, the most likely explanation for the Fed funds market’s still-notable implied possibility of the Fed holding fire is that the vast majority of traders are in fact girded for interest rate lift-off in December, but simply expect that the Fed funds future will be on the lower end of the new range. As Michael Cloherty, head of rates strategy at RBC, says: “We’re at the point where it would be a catastrophe for the Fed not to go in December.” ~~~~~ COMMENT: Those last two paragraphs are what clinch it for me (at least to raise my prediction to 100% at least ahead of the Nov. jobs report. The timing of the initial interest rate move is less important than that of the second.  The second rate hike sets the path of the tightening cycle, which will affect the path of currencies, stocks and bonds.  If the Fed raises once but then returns to its Hamlet routine, we will see similar market uncertainty as we have had over the past year, with the only difference being 25 lousy basis points.  A second rate hike, however, enables economists to employ their handy forecasting tool -- a ruler that connects the two points and then extends the trend into the future.

The Fed has stated its intent to raise interest rates, and it makes sense, perhaps, to do so now. It is probably the wrong move because the economy is not growing too quickly at all, but Yellen and Congress seem undeterred and they want the rates raised nevertheless. Implementation has yet to happen, but with the government on the same page (finally, yay!), it is likely to happen.

Key reason: Reduce anxiety at the end of the year for global markets. There is a mental/behavioral upside to getting it over with during the end of year period, commonly associated with rising consumer discretionary spending. In theory this could help negate any overreaction by the market. The economics of when matter little, I believe the main concern of the Fed is to not "trigger" something. December offers a nice shield, at least in developed markets, against knee jerk reactions. If, however, there is economic data that comes out over the next two weeks that is negative, the fear of a knee jerk reaction will escalate. This could deter the Fed's decision. Every day that no such data is released, however, increases the likelihood of rates. Another fear in this same vein are very recent fears of Turkey-Russian conflict escalation. Given the limited effects this has had thus far on European markets, the thought is that this won't have a major impact, lest one of the (relatively volatile) participants in the conflicts does something ill advised.

Regarding today's "emergency meeting". This is nothing out of the ordinary. This happens every few months & there is nothing "emergency" about it, despite what external bloggers may report. More detail: The Fed is holding a regular meeting of the board of governors to discuss the primary credit discount rate on Monday. It's the rate charged to commercial banks and other depository institutions on loans they receive from their regional Federal Reserve Bank's lending facility - the discount window - and has been at 75 bps for the primary credit program since February 2010. At the last such meeting, 5 of the 12 regional Fed banks called for a hike to said rate. However, these recommendations require support from the Board of Governors. It is highly unlikely that the Board (Yellen, Fischer, Tarullo, Powell & Brainard) will approve a discount rate move outside of a move in the fed funds target. Nothing to be concerned about & zero chance of a change today with a decision still "technically" up in the air for Dec.  I think Vice Chair Fischer put it best: "While we at the Fed continue to scrutinize incoming data, and no final decisions have been made, we have done everything we can to avoid surprising the markets and governments when we move, to the extent that several emerging market (and other) central bankers have, for some time, been telling the Fed to 'just do it'." Market implied odds this morning are pricing around ~70-75% odds with the only reason they're so low being the opportunity cost of holding a position between now and Dec 16th. Since I don't have to worry about PnL concerns with my prediction above, I'm comfortable pricing in the correct odds which I'm cuffing somewhere between 90-95%.

Broke this into two pieces. First, statements/indications from the FOMC, and second economic data that post-dates those statements. In this case, the signals telegraphing a rate increase in the last FOMC meeting, coupled with other statements from key governors indicate that the rationale for a December increase during the October meeting was strong. Since then, strong jobs numbers reported in October make this more likely.  Strong November job growth (released in early December) would make me significantly more confident in this forecast. While weak job growth may cause me to decrease strength in this forecast, the FOMC's willingness to push through with a relatively hawkish statement even after the weak September numbers would likely only push me back to the 55% range.

The action will most likely be taken on Dec. 16. That’s when the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed policy-making group that sets the target rate, concludes its next two-day meeting. Janet L. Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, is scheduled to hold a news conference that afternoon. (In the unlikely event that policy makers take no action, the next meeting dates are Jan. 26-27 and March 15-16.) The unexpectedly strong October jobs report, released in early November, has accelerated speculation that the Fed will raise rates in December. The unemployment rate now stands at 5 percent, or what normally is considered “full employment” by the Fed and many private economists. Confidence in jobs growth has replaced worries generated by last summer’s turmoil in the global economy. The slowing Chinese economy and devaluation of the renminbi, the slumping price of oil, jarring downturns in the global stock markets had all prompted questions over when will be the best time for the Fed to raise interest rates. In testimony before Congress on Nov. 4, Ms. Yellen gave some signals that the rate increase could come in December, saying: “At this point, I see the U.S. economy as performing well” and that “December would be a live possibility.” But she added a cautionary note, saying that “no decision has been made.”

Reaffirming earlier call of 0 % chance. Short term yields are falling again, as what happened prior to October's meeting.  The short end of the yield curve would be greatly destabilized should the fed even raise 25 basis points as the 1 mo and 3 mo yield are at 0.06% and 0.11% respectively.  I will raise my expectations of a rate rise if and only if the short end of the curve rises significantly from here, which I don't see happening, as a result of global and domestic growth that continue to trend in the wrong direction. Additionally, inflation  expectations remain muted and there are currently NO signs of an overheating US economy. Inflation/deflation risks remain very asymmetric as the fed can much easier combat inflation--all its tools remain--however it has fired most--if not all--of its bullets with regards to deflation... Rhetoric from the private industry, as opposed to policy makers and bureaucrats, is far more insightful and accurate--they have a self-interest in being "right", and are not motivated to try to manipulate expectations towards a desired reality. Ray Dalio, and Jeff Gundlach--just to name two big names in the private investment world, are VERY skeptical of the fed being able to raise rates given current market conditions, implying any meager rate rise would be a political move ONLY and market conditions would force an  immediate reversal. Gundlach and Dalio, smartly point to a slowing global economy, being led by extreme weakness in overseas markets, particularly Europe Japan, and China. China by the way, is in the midst of its own "1929 moment" as it is currently suffering  from an unprecedented increase in debt levels, malinvestment and overcapacity. Jim Chanos, whom I believe to be an expert on Chinese markets, has explained their situation as "whatever you think is happening in China--it's much worse." Dalio also makes the same point I made above regarding the yield curve, and the immediate destabilization a rate rise would cause absent an interest rate adjustment that reflects a higher discount rate. In laymen's terms, the treasury market is still saying short term rates  belong at/near zero. A fed raise here, would be akin to a massive intervention in a multi trillion dollar market. The entire commodities complex, most importantly oil, all reflect deflation is much closer than inflation. Commodities are hitting new 6+ year lows on a daily basis, as WTI crude oil, is struggling to find support at 40, only $1.50 above its 6 year low. High yield credit began rolling over in 2014 and is now set to take out its lowest levels since 2011, and emerge in a bear market. At this juncture, the trends in these markets are still inarguably DOWN.  Japan is in a recession (again), the Eurozone, is on the precipice of negative growth, while the ECB trends further and further into negative interest rate policy.  The dollar would jump higher if the fed should raise rates here, significantly adding to deflationary pressures...

The Fed is in a tough position.  They are walking a fine line between calming the markets and igniting more global concerns.  I am of the belief that the Fed will move in December by raising the Federal Fund rates by 25 basis points.  The Fed is anxious to get off of its zero interest rate policy.  This is their chance.  Also, if they did not go, the Fed's credibility could also be called into question.  Yellen has stated that she expects it will be appropriate at some point later this year to take the first step to raise the Fed Funds rate and thus begin normalizing monetary policy.  With an unemployment rate at 5%, the Fed now has a reason to go.  As far as inflation is concerned, improvement in labor market conditions should persist, suggesting continued modest upward pressure on wages.  Inflation should eventually reach an inflection point and slowly rise toward Fed's 2% target over the medium term.  Barring any negative surprises (remember the Fed is data dependent) such as a significant slowdown in China or a major decline in the stock market, the Fed should act in December.

I've forecasted this question a couple of times, and have recently come to the following conclusions.  First, the data today is not materially different from the data available in July/August.  Second, the Fed has information that I don't have access to, so, whatever way I rationalize my forecast, it's just a guess made on data I don't have.  The Fed has two explicit mandates: defence of the US currency and full employment.  It seems it also has an implicit goal: to temper the natural business cycle.  So, if the data doesn't make much difference, then what is the real question?  Will Janet Yellen have the courage to raise rates?  She may be swayed by arguments made by other members of the FOMC, but it's her decision in the end.  I am leaning against an increase for using the following rationalizations: 1) Inflation is slightly below target.  I believe Yellen wants err on the side of an inflation rate too high as opposed to too low. 
2) In her public statements, she only stated the "possibility" was on the table.  I take that to mean a rate increase in December is a possibility assigned a non-zero probability sufficiently high to take seriously.
3) The attack in Paris this past weekend has economic implications:  A) European nation-states will need to fund more internal security which will harm growth prospects in Europe.  B) Overall European Union growth will slow as money is diverted to social services for Middle East refugees.  C) Military coordination between the US and EU (and Russia?) with respect to ISIS is obvious.  Europeans can make the case that a degree of economic coordination is also needed.  In the past, Draghi has lobbied against a rate increase.
4) Commodities denominated in US dollars show no signs of going up.  An interest rate increase will strengthen the US dollar and will drive commodity prices even lower.  (I don't believe this is the result the Fed wants.  It's not clear if this would be good or bad for the US economy since, outside of agriculture, we aren't huge commodity producers.)

In an interview with USA Today, President of the San Francisco Fed John Williams remarked that there is a "very strong case" for the Fed to raise interest rates at its December meeting. He acknowledged that economic data released between now and next month could still influence policymakers in either direction as well as the likelihood of a gradual pace of tightening after the normalization process begins. The numbers don't support hiking rates even now. Statements like "a quarter point won't hurt" sound like the addict's "I've been good so long; just a taste won't hurt." Also, there is a hysteresis effect involved here: the damage done by raising rates too soon is harder to correct than the damage done by raising rates too late. The members of the Fed are well aware of that. If the Fed does hike rates now, it will be for political reasons, not economic ones, and the political pressure is to raise rates. Is there a political downside to keeping rates low? As Larry Wilmore repeatedly points out, "Obama don't care;" i.e., political consequences aren't important to the administration anymore. So that's a point against rate hikes. The Federal Open Market Committee operates by consensus rather than vote tally, a process that generally tends to insulate individuals in a group from retaliation. That's another point against rate hikes. My forecast is really my guess at the probability the FOMC will reach a politically motivated consensus to raise rates in the next six weeks.

It seems like the strong jobs report has the FED considering it, however there are so many other factors in play. CPI is low (near 0 for the year) and without a threat of inflation it is hard to justify a rate increase on the news that wages have made a small uptick recently.  I don't see why it seems an obvious decision to  hike rates when it appears quantitive easing may finally be helping to raise  stagnate wages for the lower and middle class workers. Several economist have pointed this out such as Paul Krugman. There is no data that I've seen that would appear to show that high inflation is a growing concern especially with such low energy prices. It would seem more prudent to wait for wages to increase to the point where a healthy moderate inflation became apparent then slowly raise rates. However, if there is another strong jobs report and any increase in energy cost I could see the Federal Reserve making a small incremental move. For one thing, having rates at near 0 takes an important tool away from the FED. If there is any hiccups in a sensitive economy and rates are at zero, the FED will simply have little they can do, even if it just a psychological effect on the market if they simply can't reduce rates lower then where they stand. This could be a small added incentive to increase rates while things are relatively stable. I think the December numbers will be critical in the final decision. Despite the recent polls of economist predicting an increase I'm more skeptical. I cant see them taking a risk of dampening the small recent growth in wages with near 0 inflation in 2015. If even a small increase has a negative effect on this growth, they will be unlikely to reduce the rates once an increase is implemented. There is also the international pressures to keep rates low. Even as the US economy seems to mildly strengthening, the global economy is fragile. An increased rate may hinder international trade and specifically hurt developing countries purchasing power. Considering the interlinked global economy and the chance that a global slowdown could trickle back into the US economy,  it would seem wiser to wait until an increase is more obviously needed then it is now. This one is close to 43% yes right for me right now with a possibility of an increase if December shows further economic progress both globally and domestically.

I vote yes. I think the fed is coming around to the realization that ultra low interest rates are having a litany of unintended affects on the US economy. Namely, that most large public companies are taking on huge debts cheaply (low interest rates plus tax write offs for debt) for the sole purpose of share buybacks and dividends. The intention of cheap capital was for companies to invest capital in infastructure and R&D. I can't really name a fortuane 500 company that took advantage of that. Low interest rates are not accomplishing their intended purpose so why keep them around? This combined with comparatively inspiring job and wage growth should be enough to convinve the fed to take the bold step of 0.25%

The US Federal Reserve has made it clear it would like to normalize rates.  Chairman Yellen made a speech (University of Massachusetts at Amherst, Sept 24, 2015) announcing as much.  It created speculation as to whether a rate increase was “date” or “data” dependent. Looking at the date aspect first, it will be very difficult for the FMOC to raise in 2016.  IMHO, this is due to US Presidential politics.  A rate increase in 2016 could be taken as favoring one political party over the other.  (I can make the case either way.)  However, the Federal Reserve needs to protect the public's perception they operate above politics.  Therefore, if they don't raise at the next opportunity (December), it is unlikely they will raise in 2016.  I'll concede they might do it very early in 2016 to give potential economic dislocations a chance to pass.  This is because rate increases have different effects than rate decreases.  They are aware of what happened in 1992 to Bush (41) in the race against Clinton in spite of the Fed's help.  The Fed lowered rates throughout 1991 (10 times!) and in 1992 (3 times) from 6.75% to 3%.  The rate decreases should have helped the incumbent party but did not.  The electorate thought the economy was suffering, and it was that perception that mattered.  (Remember “It's the economy, stupid!”?)  An interest rate increase will slow an economy which won't be a politically “helpful” thing. Now consider the data.  From a historical point of view, these low interest rates are unprecedented in records going back to the European middle ages (about 500 years).  Interest rates actually mean something extremely important for firms and economies, and rates at a zero-level are probably a bad thing.  (It's clear that any project a firm could imagine would have a positive return has been brought forward due to the time discounting.) What do I expect will happen if a rate increase (no matter how small) were to happen?  First, I expect the US stock markets to go down, but this will be temporary.  I think bonds will be hurt (in particular, high yield bonds will be hurt (eg, JNK, HYG)).  High yield bonds can be somewhat illiquid, so first equities will be liquidated to protect portfolios then bonds will be sold.  After that, money managers will move back to equities that have dividends as a replacement for high yield bond income.  There will also be net wealth inflows into the US  in the form of a currency carry trade. What do I expect will happen if there is no rate increase?  Not much change.  Can kicked down the road.  At some point this ends, but why now? The “For Rate Increase” Arguments: 1) Credibility of the Fed may be on the line.  Yellen has a place in history, and has realistic concerns over her legacy. 2) While I find monthly jobs data suspect due to how noisy the time series is and due to the adjustments, the US October data showed 271K (non-farm) jobs created.  This satisfies the Fed's employment mandate. 3) The target US inflation rate is 2%.  By the Fed's calculations, US inflation is below this value but maybe close enough. 4) A 0.25% increase is really next to nothing compared to rates over the last 30 years.  So tear the bandaid off and get it over with. 5) Commodity futures (specifically gold and silver) imply market players believe the FMOC will raise. The “Against Rate Increase” Arguments: 1) Major world economies are attempting economic easing to get their stalled economies going.  The EU is trying quantitative easing.  The Chinese PBOC has devalued the yuan.  Japan has Abe's “Three Arrows” (or even more arrows now?) program.  Can the US go it alone in the face of actions in the rest of the world?  The Fed did not raise in September.  A reason given was world markets.  This was driven by the August US market correction (which was based on what happened in Chinese markets). 2) Commodities are at relatively depressed prices.  Commodities are US dollar denominated.  Emerging markets dependent on commodities will be hurt.  Economies with currencies pegged to the US dollar will be hurt. 3) The US is funding current government spending, in part, through borrowing.  A higher interest rate will mean pressure on the US budget and debt service. 4) US inflation is below the target 2% level.  An interest rate increase will slow the economy (fewer projects make economic sense), lower economic activity, and lower inflation.  The Fed wants to err on the side of too much inflation rather than too little. What can change my forecast? 1) If the December FMOC meeting passes without a rate increase, then the probability within the question's time frame becomes very low. 2) Public pressure on the Federal Reserve from European central bankers.  In the past, Mario Draghi and Christine Lagarde have appealed to Yellen and it seems to have worked. 3) Significant market drops in the US or around the world. 4) Large changes in commodity prices.  In particular, gold seems to be sensitive to interest rates.

The thinking inside the Fed is that the economy is finally healthy enough that borrowing costs should return to more “normal” levels to help keep future inflation from accelerating too much.
. . . .
. . . Convinced that it has done as much as it considers prudent, the Fed is no longer expanding the size of its balance sheet, which reached $4.5 trillion. "Still, while the economy has rebounded, certain aspects of the recovery – like the housing sector, work force participation, and hourly wages – are spotty at best.  "Recent turmoil in the global economy has added an extra layer of risk to the Fed’s timing. The slowing Chinese economy and devaluation of the renminbi, the slumping price of oil, jarring downturns in the global stock markets and grim jobs figures in September have all prompted questions over whether when will be the best time for the Fed to raise interest rates. "In testimony before Congress on Nov. 4, Ms. Yellen gave some signals that the rate increase could come in December, saying: “At this point, I see the U.S. economy as performing well,” and that “December would be a live possibility.” But she added the cautionary note, however, saying that “no decision has been made.”  "Ever since March . . . Fed policy makers have used a standard line to describe the conditions that would warrant a rate increase: “The committee anticipates that it will be appropriate to raise the target range for the federal funds rate when it has seen further improvement in the labor market and is reasonably confident that inflation will move back to its 2 percent objective over the medium term.” "Jeffrey M. Lacker, a member of the Federal Open Market Committee, has been very vocal about the need to raise rates sooner rather than later. In a speech in September, he said: Some might argue that as long as inflation is close to 2 percent we have a free pass — we can keep supporting the real side of the economy with low rates until inflation rises. But if, as I’ve argued, the real side of the economy calls for a higher interest rate, then there is a real danger associated with this strategy. Inflation is a lagging indicator, and the forces that lead to rising inflation can build up before they are apparent in the data. "On Sept. 17, after a two-day meeting, the committee decided not to change rates, citing market worries: “Recent information on real U.S. economic activity was generally stronger than expected, but equity prices declined, the foreign exchange value of the dollar appreciated further, and indicators of foreign economic growth were generally weak.” "On Oct. 12, Lael Brainard, a member of the Federal Reserve’s board of governors, argued that the central bank should continue to exercise restraint in raising rates. “I view the risks to the economic outlook as tilted to the downside. The downside risks make a strong case for continuing to carefully nurture the U.S. recovery — and argue against prematurely taking away the support that has been so critical to its vitality.” "The following day, Daniel Tarullo, another member of the board of governors, said he did not “expect that it would be appropriate” for the Fed to start raising its benchmark rate this year. “With credit becoming more expensive, the outlook for the Chinese economy clouded at best, emerging markets submerging, the U.S. stock market in a correction, widespread concerns about liquidity, and expected volatility having increased at a near-record rate, markets are themselves dampening any euphoria or overconfidence. The Fed does not have to do the job. At this moment of fragility, raising rates risks tipping some part of the financial system into crisis, with unpredictable and dangerous results.”
— Lawrence H. Summers, former Treasury secretary, writing in The Financial Times (Aug. 23) "A rate rise is overdue, but the Fed must be very cautious: . . . The Fed is beginning to recognize that six years of zero bound interest rates have negative influences on the real economy.”
--William H. Gross, a co-founder of Pimco who now manages a fund at Janus Capital, writing in his September Investor Outlook (Sept. 2)

If it was me, I would not be raising the rates in 2015, but sometimes there are greater forces than ourselves (haha).  European Central bank has continued its QE-type policy, which strengthens the dollar and has impacted US exports. Bank of Japan remains under a lot of pressure to expand its QE position to address continuing lackluster economic performance. The Congress established the statutory objectives for monetary policy--maximum employment, stable prices, and moderate long-term interest rates--in the Federal Reserve Act.
http://www.federalreserve.gov/faqs/money_12848.htm In which there is the Taylor rule:
«Taylor Rule (by which I mean the formulation based on John’s 1993 and 1999 papers) has a number of positive attributes that make it a useful reference for policymakers. 
 First, it has two parameters—the long-term inflation objective and the level of potential output—that map directly to the Federal Reserve’s dual mandate objectives.  Second, the Rule has the desirable feature that when economic shocks push the economy away from the central bank’s objectives, the Taylor Rule prescribes a policy response that can help push the economy back toward the central bank’s goals.  Third, a number of studies have shown that Taylor Rules are robust in the sense that they generally perform quite well across a range of different assumptions about how the economy is structured and operates. »

From Forbes contributor Oliver Pursche:
"I have long considered a December rate hike unlikely. The Fed’s next meeting coincides with what is historically a thin period of trading. Investors are out on holiday, there tend to be fewer news events to trade off, and in general there’s less liquidity floating around. Raising rates in that kind of environment would amplify volatility unnecessarily, and if the Fed can avoid turbulence by waiting, it probably will.
While some of the factors that made a December hike unlikely have diminished–specifically, government risk related to budgetary brinksmanship in the legislative branch–I still think December is unlikely given continued concerns over global growth and the drop we’ve seen in third-quarter profits. Moreover, if October employment figures (set to be released on Nov. 6) come in weak, there is no justification for raising rates."

Philosophically, interest is the price of money based off of supply and demand. There is not a whole lot of aggregate demand for money at the moment, even with the economy in marginally better shape than years past. Furthermore, with global growth slowing, there will be less demand for return, and future T-Bill auctions will depress the yield even farther. Third quarter data on earnings, housing and inventories will continue to depress the economic outlook, with no indications of future growth. Energy prices will remain low, with no impetus to gain with a mild, wet winter in most of the continental US. Lastly, Chair Yellen is the epitome of Dovish, and would not want to mar the "historic" nature of her chair by lifting off too early.

Probably not.  Betting that the FED would raise rates has been a losing proposition in recent times.  Today, the FED has two imperatives:  (1) defend the currency and control inflation/deflation, and (2) encourage full employment and economic vigor.  The FED is less independent than it once was, and day-to-day politics have more of an impact on its decisions.   At every turn, the FED has found reasons not to act.   Most of the discussion involves questions about what constitutes full employment.  But other new reasons come along all the time, including recently announced monetary easing decisions in Europe and China.  Bear in mind that the FED also has an unstated third imperative no one likes to talk about.  One of the biggest beneficiaries of zero rates is the U.S. government itself.  Given the debt burden, keeping FED funds at zero has significant budgetary implications.  One day, the FED will act to raise short term rates, but when the vote comes in December, the easiest pathway will be to vote no once again.

The low rate of unemployment suggests rates should rise. However, stubbornly low inflation and economic uncertainty are reasons to delay. But economic uncertainty is abating, and low inflation is likely due to the impact of low commodity prices, which research by the St Louis Fed has shown to be temporary.  A majority of members of the committee have indicated a rise this year is likely if forecasts stay on track. In June 2015, the year 2015 was viewed at the appropriate timing of policy firming by 15 to 2 by Fed members though of course August was rocky for the markets, but then in September 13 of 17 participants made the same statement. See slide 3 of the September Fed policy statement: http://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/files/fomcprojtabl20150917.pdf Of course, rates haven't risen in many years, so it's also possible we're in a new paradigm of low rates forever, but that seems improbable because new paradigms seldom happen in finance.  Raising rates would also give the Fed some ammunition/room should the economy weaken, which is desirable. However, the Fed would rather raise too late than too early, because recession is viewed as a less correctable and more serious problem than rising inflation.  What the Fed say they are going to do is data that should have a significant weight in this decision. They are saying that they will raise rates in 2015. The material risk is that the economic data worsens, either via a materially worse US jobs situation (5% chance) or even worse inflation news (10% chance) or more bleak international news (15% chance). These chances are fairly small as only 2 months left in the year at this point, so the time for negative change is limited. The chance of all three of these things not happening and the Fed remaining on course is 73%.

Two of the governors of the Federal Reserve, Lael Brainard and Daniel Tarullo, have recently spoken out against a rise in interest rates this year. Janet Yellen has seemed to lean in that direction as well. ( http://www.businessinsider.com/lael-brainard-downside-economy-risks-2015-10 ) The economy is not doing very well, job growth has slowed, the level of median wages has stagnated rather than rising which it would do with an improving economy. Those measures weigh against a rate increase, which would further slow the economy. Slowing the economy increases the risk of actual deflation, which is very difficult to remedy with monetary measures — theory says that it would require a negative interest rate, which is impossible to achieve in practice. The Fed won't sell bonds above their face value; banks won't charge customers for the privilege of banking their money.

The economy is still weak, and the Fed is learning that interest rates can be somewhat controlled even at the zero lower bound. On the other hand, problems in China  and other developing countries could force these countries to a sell-off of US treasuries at a greater rate. This would incentivize the Federal Reserve to keep the rates low at least until next year when they are more certain (hopefully) that developing nations are not going to have a demand shock. On the other hand, the current success with interest rates at the zero lower bound does not last, they may be forced to raise rates. Also, if the banks are unwilling to cooperate with such low interest rates treasuries being forced onto them, the private side of the Federal Reserve would try to steer monetary policy towards higher rates. If bankers are squeezed, which is unlikely, they may not be able to handle such low rates. The most important factor, however, is the stick market from now until December 31st. If the stock market does very well, the Fed may think it can raise rates again. On the other hand, this may also signal a bubble which is not a sign of real growth. Depending on where we actually are in the business cycle (which is hard to determine itself) there may be real reason to raise rates in November/December. I think the Fed will play cautiously, however, and enjoy their newly-discovered powers at the zero lower bound until at least early 2016.

There is a lot of political pressure to raise rates, but inflation simply isn't present. Using a "pre-emptive strike" for raising rates just doesn't make academic sense to me. I agree there is a lot of political pressure to raise rates and general concern in the marketplace about leaving rates at zero for so many years, but I fail to see the academic argument supporting an immediate rate rise and I think the folks at the Fed will ultimately agree. The argument has gone from an academic one to a psychological one - "raise rates now to get the wait over with." I don't think this holds academic mustard. The Fed is independent enough to make the correct economic decision regardless of the political noise surrounding the Fed's decision to keep rates so low for so long. If inflation appears the Fed can always quickly adjust up rates if need be at subsequent meetings.

There are at least three conflicting factors towards the decision process here: * The dual inflation-growth mandate of the Fed. This is, by default ("naïve macro", we could call it) my main concern, and it makes me puzzled at the idea that rates would raise under zero inflation and fledgling growth. But: naive macro and the Philips curve are borked right now - perspectives of long-term ZIRP may produce bizarro monetary economics, and unlike in the third world where standard hyperkeynesiana ideology deems high rates a necessary, preferably avoided evil, mainstream discourse in the USA may be more worried about bubble-inflating scenarios under comic-book Austrian theory. * Disequilibrium feedback loops by which hurting third world economies harms the American economy. It's not easy to gauge how much this "matters" to Fed decision-making, but it's certainly higher on priority lists now that China has begun to decelerate. I don't understand Yellen enough from an ideological POV, critically: has she spoken on TPP, for example? * Long-term concerns about the dollar's status as default reserve currency. The senior economists I speak to on a regular basis see this as about par with California's Big One earthquake -- it's there, but too catastrophic to even think about. But yet -- American monetary authorities more than anyone else should be well aware of the extraordinary economic advantages that come from reserve currency status; and China's new currency manipulation manoeuvres already involve some significant bond dumping. Note that this is in direct opposition to action in response to the disequilibrium feedback loops I've just mentioned.  All of this said, I'm moving halfway towards consensus; valid worries about point #2 have been convincingly put. I should try and have an adjustment model in OBPs for those three points in the future.

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/21/opinion/paul-krugman-the-rage-of-the-bankers.html?emc=edit_th_20150921&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=28699183 SEPT. 21, 2015 " . . .  the Federal Reserve chose not to raise interest rates. It was the right decision. In fact, I’m among the economists wondering why we’re even thinking about raising rates right now. "But the financial industry’s response may explain what’s going on. You see, the Fed talks a lot to bankers — and bankers reacted to its decision with sheer, unadulterated rage. For those trying to understand the political economy of monetary policy, it was an “Aha!” moment. Suddenly, a lot of what has been puzzling about the discussion makes sense: just follow the money. "The basic principles of interest rate policy are fairly simple. . .  If rates are too low, inflation will accelerate; if rates are too high, inflation will fall and perhaps turn into deflation. "By this criterion, it’s hard to argue that current rates are too low. . . . the Fed’s preferred inflation measure . . . has consistently fallen short of its own target of 2 percent, and shows no sign of rising. " rates  . . . are very low by historical standards. And it’s interesting to ask why the economy seems to need such low rates. But all the evidence says that it does. Again, if you think that rates are much too low, where’s the inflation? "Yet the Fed has faced constant criticism for its low-rate policy. Why? "The answer is that the story keeps changing. . . . The justification du jour is “financial stability,” the claim that low interest rates breed bubbles and crashes. "I suppose this latest excuse for raising rates could be right. But it’s striking how convoluted and dubious the case for rate hikes has become. . . .  " . . . when you see ever-changing rationales for never-changing policy demands, it’s a good bet that there’s an ulterior motive. And the rate rage of the bankers — combined with the plunge in bank stocks that followed the Fed’s decision not to hike — offers a powerful clue to the nature of that motive. It’s the bank profits, stupid. " . . .  What’s clear . . .  is that low rates are bad for bankers. "For banks make their profits by taking in deposits and lending the funds out at a higher rate of interest. And this business gets squeezed in a low-interest environment: the rates banks can charge on loans are pushed down, but rates on deposits can only go so low. The net-interest margin — the difference between the interest rate banks receive on loans and the rate they pay on deposits — has fallen sharply over the past five years. "The appropriate response of policy makers to this observation should be, “So?” There’s no reason to believe that what’s good for bankers is good for America. But bankers are different from you and me: they have a lot more influence. Monetary officials meet with them all the time, and in many cases expect to join their ranks when they come out on the other side of the revolving door. Also, it’s widely assumed that bankers have special expertise on economic policy, although nothing in the record supports this belief. . . .  "So we shouldn’t be surprised to see institutions that cater to bankers, not to mention much of the financial press, spinning elaborate justifications for a rate hike that makes no sense in terms of basic economics. And the debate of the past few months, in which the Fed has seemed weirdly eager to raise rates despite warnings from the likes of Larry Summers that it would be a terrible mistake, suggests that even U.S. monetary officials aren’t immune.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  This was (rightly) an op-ed piece, but it explained a lot of things for me, like why Larry Summers was opposed to raising the rate while so many others were urging & expecting it.

Inching up.  Per Janet Yellen's comments of yesterday.  But I usually don't hang out at this end of the scale (unless its Russian fighter jets in Syria) without a feeling of near certainty.  The consensus among the majority of economists is that it will be important for the Fed to begin to recoup the use of its most effective tool (until the advent of quantitative easing) which has been the Fed Funds rate.  This has been extensively reported since the end of QE3 (or was that 4?). Looking at market projections of a 3-3.5% rate expectation in the coming year (Bloomberg) and the reaction by the markets to the results of the most recent Fed meeting demonstrates that the markets want an increase in the base rate (a rate increase would be perceived as a vote of confidence in the domestic economy and an acknowledgement that the issues in China and the weaker Euro markets may not have as large a domestic impact as initially thought).  Couple her remarks with the news today that GDP rose more than previously estimated for the second quarter (3.9% vs 3.7%, median expectations were at 3.7%).  Growth in the second quarter was fueled by increased consumer and investment in commercial and residential construction, both segments of the economy that generally leverage broad based growth throughout the economy.  Her remarks yesterday pretty well seal the deal as I see it. But if this does not occur, my brier score is in for a rough period of its own.

Lowering prob. A couple of notes: -The October meeting doesn't have a press conference, so chances are they won't do anything there. This has become messy enough that they'll want a press conference to help Wall St. work through its tantrums.
-They are watching China: “Recent global economic and financial developments may restrain economic activity somewhat and are likely to put further downward pressure on inflation in the near term.” That's about as explicit as the Fed gets.
-They are paying attention to inflation: "If China’s economy continues to slow, exporting deflation with it, then the chances are that the Fed will continue to keep US interest rates at zero." http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/5f4a78c0-5d79-11e5-a28b-50226830d644.html#axzz3mNoAHEMa
-Inflation is low and will remain so for a while. "Bond-market measures of inflation expectations known as break-even rates show traders predict prices to drop about 1.5 percent in the next year. Costs will barely budge in the next 24 months, a similar metric indicates." http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-15/bonds-back-baring-asset-in-upending-fed-inflation-forecasts In a general finger-in the-wind sense, I get the impression that people are paying less attention to arguments about raising rates because everything is "normal" now and starting to squint at the data more carefully. Here's what I think will be required for a rate hike in December: -Some signs of increased core inflation. (I don't think this will happen. Strong $, low oil.)
-China keeps a lid on its markets. (Maybe.)
-U.S. wage growth that is solid bordering on impressive. (This is unlikely to occur before end of year since most businesses have planned out their employment needs for the rest of the year this point and I think  we'll continue to see the same cautious optimism that we have seen all year. My gut feeling is that wages may pick up in 1H16 if things continue to go relatively well in 2015.)

On the one hand, it is easy to say that after 63 Fed meetings without budging, a rate increase is overdue. On the other hand, see comparison classes: The Fed normally only raises rates in a strong economy. While the U.S. economy remains strong, if China sneezes, the world catches a cold. If China were to be rushed to the ICU, falling dominoes could cause another Great Recession. (There, am I the queen of mixed metaphors or not?) Logical analysis:  See the comparison class  of previous Fed meetings Does each meeting lead to a decision on the basis of the current situation only? Does it factor past decisions into the analysis, for example after 63 decisions to not increase the rate, could this mean a change is overdue? Does the Fed make forecasts that include the world economy? It seems to me that the sunk costs fallacy is not relevant to Fed rate increases. So a long string of no decisions should not lead to an emotional prediliction to keep on saying no as a way of validating the sunk costs, so to speak, of so many no decisions. Also, neither can we apply the gambler's fallacy that after an unusual number in a row of double snake eyes in a dice game, the goddess of luck must be ready for yet another -- dice are HOT!! Or the goddess is more likely that average to make the dice come up double sixes!  My reasoning is that the Fed comprises analysts of sufficient knowledge of probability and statistics that each meeting considers only the current situation, and develops forecasts of alternate futures based upon good data combined with this mathematical sophistication. I also am going with the proposition that these forecasts include the world economy. Indeed, given (metaphor alert!) the three ton gorilla (are they ever that big?) of China, and the many indications that its economy is in more trouble than China's official reports, I'm ready to hoard platinum somewhere deep in one of our ranch's haystacks. Just kidding, but there are people like our neighbor the retired econ professor who aren't kidding. Sources:  Dateline 9-18-15 Holger Zschaepitz ‏@Schuldensuehner  [senior editor of the financial and economic desk at @Welt] Berlin, Germany

Source: Dateline 9-18-15 "The Fed's honesty about the international situation introduced the worrying implication that it is not in control of its own destiny. Now it is dependent not just on US economic and market data but on movements in an economy on the other side of the world. If China's economy continues to slow, exporting deflation with it, then the chances are that the Fed will continue to keep US interest rates at zero," writes John Authers in the Financial Times. "Ms Yellen's focus on the labour market, then, does not mean that the Fed is ignoring the world economy. Quite the opposite; the gloomier the world outlook, the stronger the labour market must perform to justify a rate rise. In the coming months, markets should look to the world, as well as the jobs data, to predict when interest rates will, at last, take off," writes the Economist. "China will remain a global risk and contagion a global concern. The challenge is that these scenarios will take some time to play out, and in any case it could be many months before they are ruled in or out. At some point, the Fed will need to accept that global risks and the volatility they generate are an enduring feature of markets and not a reason for indefinite inaction," writes CFR's Robert Kahn in a blog post. I'm still pretty confident that the Federal Reserve will increase rates by the end of the year. Most of the FOMC members still expect a rate rise by the end of the year http://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/files/fomcprojtabl20150917.pdf
Despite some articles' emphasis on global market turbulence and financial outlook, that still isn't a major concern for the FOMC as the US economy is still pretty strong and exports make up 12.7% of US GDP. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-17/fed-leaves-interest-rates-unchanged-at-zero-0-25-target-range
Unemployment is pretty much where the Federal Reserve wants it to be and consumer spending is high. Expectations are that both will remain strong. It also seems that inflation needs only seem to be able to reach 2% in the medium term for the Federal Reserve to confidently move rates upwards. So if the labour market continues to strengthen, then inflation will be seen to be following. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-17/yellen-may-emulate-taper-template-and-raise-rates-in-december I also don't think that the recent turbulence in Chinese financial markets will be repeated on as large a scale in the future. I think some people underestimate what China's centrally planned economy can do. When China says that its going to reach GDP growth of 7%, it will reach 7%.

Two more FOMC meetings before year-end: 27 October and 16 December. Probably no change in October, but December could go either way. There is some political pressure for at least a slight bump up, but whether and how much is likely to depend on economic indicators (at least based on recent FOMC decisions).
As I hinted last time, the increase in September didn't happen. We still have 3 months to go, but the Fed has signalled that it is sensitive to economic changes.

With the current rates at historic lows, federal interest rates need to be raised to stimulate inflation back to a recommended level closer to 2% annually. It also allows the Fed more wiggle room should the global stagnation push us back into recession.

Though the probability for September was small, by staying out the Feds have slightly reduced the probability that this question will resolves as "yes". Each time the decide to wait, they give themselves another month to get some bad news or good news. Since the medium-term global outlook is flat-to-poor, the odds are they will get bad news.

I don't think the Fed will raise interest rates this year. Ask yourself, why does the Federal Reserve need to raise interest rates? Normally, when the Federal Reserve raises interest rates (in order to increase economic activity) the consequence of doing so is inflation. However, the inflation rate (CPI index) is very depressed right now. The money velocity of the monetary base is at historic lows...So I ask again, why does the Fed need to raise interest rates? What is the consequence of not doing so?

FED did not raise rates in September, but expressly said it was a close vote. The FED wants to create flexibility for the future by starting the rate rise. They also look at 6 months or more, so will position themselves with a hike. Rate hike likely in December.

COMMENT:  When you're at the bottom there's only one way to go--up--so sooner or later, there will be an increase.   The longer it remains unchanged, the greater the probability that it will change.  However, change seems to be like the light at the end of a tunnel which never gets nearer.  Time and again predictions about when the Fed might raise its rate have been shifted into the more distant future--because unemployment is too high, or inflation is too low and inflation targets haven't been met, or the dollar is getting too strong, or the markets are in upheaval, or China is in crisis, or they can't agree--there's always a reason.  Now, I'm even reading that some think a rate increase may be delayed until into 2016, and that there's no need to because the markets have already adjusted as if one had occurred.   If the Fed doesn't do it at their meeting next week I'll be reducing my forecast.

The Fed has been announcing that an increase in the US federal funds rate would occur this year since January and, even though inflation remains low, Yellen doesn't want the Fed to lose its credibility by not hiking rates when it said it was going to. Long term, keeping the institution's credibility intact is more important to the US economy than what it does or does not do with interest rates at this juncture. Plus, with consistently strong monthly job gains, the unemployment rate is just over 5% and Janet Yellen is reportedly watching this indicator more closely than any other, and the funds rate will likely be increased just fractions of a percentage point, too little to sway the economy in any significant way.

The case for an increase is due to solid job gains, lower unemployment rate and a rebound in wages in July/Aug. In addition, economic growth accelerated in the second quarter after bad weather constrained it at the start of the year.

The Fed has held off on rate increases even as unemployment numbers have dropped below their stated threshold. The US is a relatively bright spot in the global economy, but there is still significant structural weakness which makes a rate hike risky. There is still significant risk of a global shock. The impact of China's slowing growth on the rest of the world's economies is really only just becoming evident with the recent stock market hiccup.  Still I think the Fed is going to make a best effort to unwind things so they have more tools for the next downturn.

Fed wants to raise, and has signaled a raise, for a long time. They keep hoping the data will support this decision, but it hasn't yet. Almost all economic reasons to raise rates involve inflation somehow. Inflation isn't at it's 2% target, and leading indicators aren't signalling that it will get there anytime soon: dollar up; commodities down; wages growing but not spectacularly; deflation present in many places globally. If there start to be signs that inflation is moving up in any meaningful way, I'll raise my prediction to the 75-80% range. If China crashes hard or some other economic bogeyman pops up (Greek elections, anyone?), I'll lower it to perhaps <50%.

I think that, as always, the Federal Reserve's decision will come down to whether a decision to increase interest rates will mean that the US economy is closer to maximum employment and 2% inflation ( http://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/press/monetary/20150729a.htm ). There are uncertainties relating to the US labour market http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-08/these-three-charts-illustrate-the-fed-s-labor-market-dilemma , even though the labour market seems fine with unemployment down to 5.1%. Normally, there is the concern that unemployment near 5% would drive up inflation, but that hasn't been happening according to the data.  So ultimately, I think inflation is what will decide whether interest rates rise or not, as raising interest rates means that inflation will decrease ( http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/b1ebac86-556b-11e5-9846-de406ccb37f2.html#axzz3lFVudG6t ). With inflation still under 2%, I don't think the Federal Reserve will increase interest rates and run the risk of the US economy declining as a result. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-08-19/fed-still-concerned-by-low-inflation-as-rate-liftoff-approaches As for the opinions of the IMF and WorldBank, whilst they are valid, they ultimately shouldn't affect the Federal Reserve's decision too much as they are naturally concerned more about the global economy than just the US economy. I'm guessing that a rate rise in September is pretty unlikely, as the market has estimated, but as for a decision in December (apparently Yellen likes to make rate change announcements at a press conference right after the FOMC meeting, which is only scheduled for September or December), its probably a bit early to say. Clearer indications will of course appear once the September FOMC meeting occurs next week.

I'm really wrestling with one thing in particular:  For FOREVER, the FRB has had a reputation - it moves too early and too much to raise, and too late and too little to drop, but this group seems to be a little different than prior governors.  Dare I call them "doves"?  If they don't move, next week, it's time to really rethink what they're going to do, because, October is coming.

Economic indicators will play a role in the decision to raise rates. But other, irrational factors will play a role, too. http://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/08/24/rate-hike-fever/
"Larry Summers argues that a Fed rate hike would be a big mistake; I completely agree. Yet he also suggests that the Fed “seems set” to do this foolish thing. Why? Pressure from the usual suspects — the constant sniping against easy money — may play a role. But I also suspect that a lot has to do with the urge to resume a conventional central ­banker role. The whole culture of central banks involves saying no to stuff people want, taking away the punch bowl the party gets going, having the courage to do unpopular things; everyone wants to be Paul Volcker. The Fed is really, really eager to return to that position — and is, I fear, engaging in wishful thinking, believing much too readily that a return to normalcy is appropriate." http://www.cepr.net/blogs/beat-the-press/washington-post-ed-board-federal-reserve-board-cultists
"The Federal Reserve Board Cultists adhere to a bizarre belief that the 19 members (12 voting) of the Federal Reserve Board’s Open Market Committee (FOMC) live in a rarified space where the narrow economic concerns of specific interest groups don’t impinge on their thinking. According to the cultists, when the Fed sits down to decide on its interest rate policy they are acting solely for the good of the country. Those of us who live in the reality-based community know that the Fed is hugely responsive to the interests of the financial sector."
It is time to start to nudge economics back toward reality.

However, the Fed has been signalling a rise for over a year now and they probably feel a 0.25% increase before year's end will show their seriousness without doing too much harm. Inflation is negligible and though the employment rate is close to what used to be considered full employment, real wages remain practically stagnant. Easy money is going into speculation which could end up in another financial crisis down the road. Ultimately it depends which pointers the Fed considers more important. Seems unlikely this month but  much more probable before the end of the year.

"For much of 2015, John Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, has projected a rosy U.S. economic outlook, seeing solid output growth, steady unemployment declines and an approaching need to increase short-term interest rates.
Now, as the Fed weighs whether to raise rates at its policy meeting next week, the optimistic economist has many caveats.
...
In June, Mr. Williams projected two interest-rate increases this year. These days he hedges on whether the Fed will act even once. It depends, he said, on how the central bank assesses the new risks that have materialized in the past few months. If the risks don’t appear to be seriously threatening, then he could see “interest-rate increases some time later this year, or an interest-rate increase.”
...
However, he’s concerned about headwinds to the outlook. The change in financial conditions since the July Fed meeting, in the form of falling stock prices and a rising dollar, “have been pretty big,” he said. “It’s not the case that nothing has changed since our last [policy] meeting.” A counter-argument:
